block.p: AT&T to Consider Strategy At Annual Board Retreat As AT&T's board prepares for its annual retreat, where many of the company's most important decisions have taken shape in recent years, the participants will most likely be discussing options meant to underline the value of the company's relatively strong operations, like its cable unit, while quarantining the performance of the relative laggards, like consumer long-distance.

Analysts and investors have also wondered about more exotic possibilities, like a full or partial merger of AT&T and British Telecommunications, as the company seeks ways to bolster a stock that closed at $32.25 last week, compared with more than $60 at one point last spring. Market Place. [C2.]

Athletes' Fund Raises $150 Million Champion Ventures, the investment fund for professional athletes started by two former San Francisco 49ers, has finished its second round of financing in as many years, raising $150 million. That is a considerable sum given that last year Ronnie Lott, left, who founded Champion with Harris Barton, raised $40 million from football stars like Keyshawn Johnson and hockey players like Wayne Gretzky. Champion invests money in the funds of some of the most prestigious venture capitalists, including Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers and Accel Partners. [C9.]

Military Agency's Technology Payoff For more than 40 years, the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency has parceled out billions of dollars for research projects, and no other organization has so frequently if unintentionally served as midwife to the technologies of today's information-driven economy. At a recent symposium, the agency said the next decade or two was likely to bring extremes in miniaturization like molecule-size computers and six-inch spy planes. New Economy. [C4.]

Sites Turn to Auditors on Privacy One of the more imposing tasks for Internet companies has been breaking through the wall of mistrust that separates them from millions of would-be shoppers who fret about online privacy. Some companies are now paying well-known financial services firms to audit their Web sites and state whether their privacy policies are more than just pixels on the screen. In doing so, analysts and privacy advocates said, these Web sites are putting pressure on other e-commerce companies to follow suit. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. [C12.]

Bloomberg Television in Cable Deal Bloomberg Television will announce a distribution deal today with Time Warner Cable that could eventually more than double the number of households its cable television channel reaches in the United States. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. [C17.]

Crime Reporter Is Shot in Canada The day after Le Journal de Montreal published a report by Michel Auger, regarded as the best-informed reporter on Montreal's underworld, on the latest killings in a turf war between two drug gangs, the Hell's Angels and the Rock Machine, an assailant shot Mr. Auger five time in the back. Mr. Auger survived but is in serious condition. Advocates for the news media noted that while physical attacks on reporters in North America are rare, attacks by criminals on journalists are on the rise worldwide. [C15.]

Microsoft Loses a Key Strategist With the retirement last week of Paul Maritz, who oversaw Microsoft's rise to operating system supremacy, the company lost a field general from the company's bitter computer wars of the 1990's. [C12.]

Joint Bid Considered for Liquor Unit Allied Domecq, the British beverage conglomerate, has discussed joining with Vin and Sprit, the Swedish company that owns Absolut vodka, to bid for Seagram's liquor business. Allied's main competitor, Diageo is already teaming up with Pernod Ricard of France to bid for the business. [C8.]
